"If you've attended live theatre, then you know it's a different and pretty extraordinary experience to see that play performed right in front of you. We're going to investigate how that experience is produced, and what it's meant throughout history to theater going audiences; theater going, at least when they aren't running of to go see rope dancers, or consorting with prostitutes, or heading out to grab a beer and a chicken leg. Audiences are tricky, but we say it's worth staying in your seat. Why? Because theatre is the art from most like life. It's performed by real people, in real space, in real time, and it's often a way to work out our ideas about the social conflicts and problems of the day. Theatre is a laboratory for life. Plays explore how people feel about government, and religion, and birth, and death, and love, and each other... and sometimes they explore how it's funny to put on a wig and tell lewd jokes, so really just something for everyone." -Alexis Soloski
I just really wanted to highlight that particular stretch of the script, a great piece of descriptive oratory!

Now I want a series about acting!!!!

As a French person, I hope the long French play mentioned is NOT Le Soulier de Santin by Claudel (though I mean, it's probably it).
In the history in French theater, the most interesting things are the two times people rioted in theaters: for the opening night of Ruy Blas, by Victor Hugo (controversial because of the politics related to monarchy) et for the opening night of Les Paravents, by Jean Genet (in the 1960', because of the Algerian war setting, in the context of the end of colonisation).

We do still have fun in the theater. I once attended an 8 hours long play that was the first half of a show, by Ariane Mnouchkine & I once attended a day long (12h total) showing of 3 Molière's plays in le théâtre de l'Odéon where at one point they completely opened the doors at the back of the stage, so the people in the street behind the theater could see the play & us & vice-versa.

The most shocking thing I have seen, though, was at a public theater, with my German teacher in attendance, the first play of Bertolt Brecht, Baal, in it's first version he wrote in his early twenties to shock the bourgeoisie & proceeded to revise twice afterward because it was just too much, even for him. The main character strolled around naked on stage & he peed on the floor. Classic public theater, I attended at 15 because my teacher recommanded it.
